I see you made #705. I update my conda repo and I've had a good look at main_search.py. W.r.t how the matching is done, in resolve.py I think it would be superior to do all matching and filtering in Resolve.get_pkgs(), after this line:

pkgs = [Package(fn, self.index[fn]) for fn in self.find_matches(ms)]

because the pkgs items (which are Package objects) are fully filterable because the fields are directly accessible. In the earlier MatchSpec object, everything has to be done via fn splits. The strictness thing inside Matchspec also seems superfluous (actually messy) since the filtering and matching could get done much more easily on the Package object fields themselves inside get_pkgs(). However, I've only looked at the code for a few minutes; thoughts?

I am considering putting a patch/PR together that applies search filters on the pkg objects, rather than fn matching, unless you or someone else at continuum is going to jump on this in the short term. The goal would be to easily do something like e.g. conda search numpy -b py34 for numpy builds valid for py34, or even conda search -b py34 for all packages valid for py34.
text:
I see you made #705.  I update my conda repo and I've had a good look at `main_search.py`.  W.r.t how the matching is done, in `resolve.py` I think it would be superior to do all matching and filtering in `Resolve.get_pkgs()`, after this line:
```
pkgs = [Package(fn, self.index[fn]) for fn in self.find_matches(ms)]
```
because the `pkgs` items (which are `Package` objects) are fully filterable because the fields are directly accessible.  In the earlier `MatchSpec` object, everything has to be done via `fn` splits.  The `strictness` thing inside `Matchspec` also seems superfluous (actually messy) since the filtering and matching could get done much more easily on the `Package` object fields themselves inside `get_pkgs()`.  However, I've only looked at the code for a few minutes; thoughts?  

I am considering putting a patch/PR together that applies search filters on the `pkg` objects, rather than `fn` matching, unless you or someone else at continuum is going to jump on this in the short term.   The goal would be to easily do something like e.g. `conda search numpy -b py34` for numpy builds valid for py34, or even `conda search -b py34` for all packages valid for py34.

There's conda search which allows you to see all versions of a package -e.g. 

conda search dateutil | grep py27

dateutil                     1.5                      py27_0  defaults
                          .  2.1                      py27_0  defaults
                             2.1                      py27_1  defaults
                          *  2.1                      py27_2  defaults

but is there an easy way to see what the latest version of a package is? Ideally programmatically but it seems it might be a handy function for the command line too, possibly as an argument --latest to conda search.
text:
There's conda search which allows you to see *all* versions of a package -e.g. 
```
conda search dateutil | grep py27

dateutil                     1.5                      py27_0  defaults
                          .  2.1                      py27_0  defaults
                             2.1                      py27_1  defaults
                          *  2.1                      py27_2  defaults
```
 but is there an easy way to see what the *latest* version of a package is? Ideally programmatically but it seems it might be a handy function for the command line too, possibly as an argument `--latest` to conda search.

Is this something that is a) already possible? or b) not implemented but definitely feasible?

html:
I tried to build a package which uses the the git describe env vars for the version but it initially picks up the git describe from the last package I built which in this case was ipython.

This is a problem because the git describe from the ipython checkout isn't a valid package name causing the build of the new package to abort:
Error: bad character '-' in package/version: 3.0.0-dev.post2568.g85b118a

The solution is simple - go delete the conda-bld/work dir. Has anyone else seen this behaviour? This is on Windows.
text:
I tried to build a package which uses the the git describe env vars for the version but it initially picks up the git describe from the last package I built which in this case was ipython.

This is a problem because the git describe from the ipython checkout isn't a valid package name causing the build of the new package to abort:
`Error: bad character '-' in package/version: 3.0.0-dev.post2568.g85b118a`

The solution is simple - go delete the `conda-bld/work` dir. Has anyone else seen this behaviour? This is on Windows.

html: i find it a bit disturbing that I’m blocked from using conda update —all just because the basemap package does not fit to the most recent matplotlib package. This is true for several months now. I know I can update single packages but I’m afraid that I might miss an update, that’s why I like to be able to do update —all. Currently, I always do an conda install basemap to enforce a downgrade of matplotlib, followed by an update —all and a finishing install matplotlib to upgrade MPL again. Is there a way I can tell conda myself that basemap-1.0.7-np19py27_0 works fine with matplotlib-1.4.2-np19py27_0 ?
text: i find it a bit disturbing that I’m blocked from using `conda update —all` just because the basemap package does not fit to the most recent matplotlib package. Currently, I always do an `conda install basemap` to enforce a downgrade of matplotlib, followed by an `update —all` and a finishing `install matplotlib` to upgrade MPL again. Is there a way I can tell `conda` myself that basemap-1.0.7-np19py27_0 works fine with matplotlib-1.4.2-np19py27_0 ?

html: a single = is a little different. It means any version in that series.
text: a single `=` is a little different. It means any version in that series.

html: so python=3.4 can mean 3.4.0 or 3.4.1 or 3.4.2
text: so `python=3.4` can mean 3.4.0 or 3.4.1 or 3.4.2

html: a single = is usually what you want from the command line.
text: a single `=` is usually what you want from the command line.

html: I find that pretty surprising actually. When I specify I want a package "equal" to a specific version I'd expect to get that version. You've overloaded "=" to actually mean ">=" which seems pretty non-obvious. If you can distinguish between  "=" and "==" there's probably no reason you can't just use ">=" directly and make the single equals a syntax error or simply equivalent to "==" for (better) backwards compatibility.
text: I find that pretty surprising actually. When I specify I want a package "equal" to a specific version I'd expect to get that version. You've overloaded "=" to actually mean ">=" which seems pretty non-obvious. If you can distinguish between  "=" and "==" there's probably no reason you can't just use ">=" directly and make the single equals a syntax error or simply equivalent to "==" for (better) backwards compatibility.

html:
I was actually put on to the single equals variant by Ilan:
https://groups.google.com/a/continuum.io/d/msg/conda/s6GbcODB8D0/NgR4nX1qiZIJ

But it's definitely not the same. I see it is documented though:
https://groups.google.com/a/continuum.io/d/msg/conda/s6GbcODB8D0/NgR4nX1qiZIJ

...but I think it probably deserves a big warning sign. After all if I wanted python=3.4* I could easily have written that myself without any magic translation required.

Regarding my earlier problem of the egg-dir, I've created a repository to demo the problem:
https://github.com/dhirschfeld/demo

I've manually patched my `conda-build`:
```
C:\dev\bin\Anaconda\Lib\site-packages\conda_build>conda list conda-build
# packages in environment at C:\dev\bin\Anaconda:
#
conda-build               1.10.2                   py27_0

C:\dev\bin\Anaconda\Lib\site-packages\conda_build>grin preserve_egg_dir post.py
post.py:
   74 : def remove_easy_install_pth(files, preserve_egg_dir=False):
   83 :             if preserve_egg_dir or not any(join(egg_path, i) in absfiles for i in walk_prefix(egg_path, False)):
  144 : def post_process(files, preserve_egg_dir=False):
  145 :     remove_easy_install_pth(files, preserve_egg_dir=preserve_egg_dir)
```

And building the demo repository results in the package available at:
https://github.com/dhirschfeld/demo/releases/download/0.2.0.pre/demo-0.1.0.post1.g132ec9e-py27_0.tar.bz2

...which as can be seen contains a `.egg` dir and a `demo.pth` file.

HTH,
Dave

html: i bet it has something to do with the recent update of setuptools, b/c this is cleary a setuptools error. I had this myself when I was still using distutils instead of the newer setuptools, my projects would just not compile under Py3.4, always with this ‘unorderable types’ error message. After changing to pure setuptools only everything worked. But now it seems something was messed up. I made another Py3.4 environment where everything works fine (also with my PYTHONPATH), but this is in conda ROOT, so I would prefer to make this work again.

html: I was able to get to the bottom of my pip failures: python-dateutil was doubly-installed. I darkly remember that it first came in via a pip install and a later conda install installed the same version again. I don’t know the precise version files, sorry, as I frantically was removing everything that appeared twice when i added debug print outs in the add function of the pkg_resources/add function. See here for exactly how I found it: https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/2353#issuecomment-85053274
text: I was able to get to the bottom of my pip failures: python-dateutil was doubly-installed. I darkly remember that it first came in via a pip install and a later conda install installed the same version again. I don’t know the precise version files, sorry, as I frantically was removing everything that appeared twice when i added debug print outs in the add function of the pkg_resources/add function. See here for exactly how I found it: https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/2353#issuecomment-85053274

html: hi all. We got some packages on a custom binstar channel: https://binstar.org/obspy/obspy/files. We recently updated the packages creating a _1 version of the packages. Now on OSX conda install -c obspy obspy still picks up the old version. Any clue as to why or how to debug this?
text: hi all. We got some packages on a custom binstar channel: https://binstar.org/obspy/obspy/files. We recently updated the packages creating a `_1` version of the packages. Now on OSX `conda install -c obspy obspy` still picks up the old version. Any clue as to why or how to debug this?

text:
@asmeurer, when I am in a conda  environment and have an extension module installed that links against libpython
otool -L is:
```
libpy_region.so:
	/usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1213.0.0)
	libpython2.7.dylib (compatibility version 2.7.0, current version 2.7.0)
	/usr/lib/libc++.1.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 120.0.0)
```
are there any problems that the wrong libpython gets loaded somehow? I am getting a `PyThreadState_Get: no current thread` error, and as far as I can see `libpython` is the only library that could be the cause.

html: you can try using install_name_tool to change the load name so that it loads the right one
text: you can try using `install_name_tool` to change the load name so that it loads the right one

My usecase is that I want to include the (repo) owner and branch names in the (dev) version string to disambiguate between upstream builds. My thought was to use the @ symbol for the sha but it's unavailable. - e.g.
1.17.0.dev011+dhirschfeld~relax_naming@gde031f3
Would it be possible to relax this restriction?
text:
My usecase is that I want to include the (repo) owner and branch names in the (dev) version string to disambiguate between upstream builds. My thought was to use the `@` symbol for the sha but it's unavailable. - e.g.
``1.17.0.dev011+dhirschfeld~relax_naming@gde031f3``
Would it be possible to relax this restriction?

html: probably. I don't know why @ is in there

html: ...possibly because it wouldn't be PEP-440 compliant. It seems unnecessarily restrictive to forbid all punctuation in the local version specifier, but there you go.
text: ...possibly because it wouldn't be PEP-440 compliant. It seems unnecessarily restrictive to forbid all punctuation in the *local* version specifier, but there you go.

Hello, I have a question about anaconda installs on mac when installing as a user.

I noticed that in addition to the `site-packages` directory, the directory `./local/lib/site-packages` was also added in the python path, which I guess is ok.
However, for some reason, packages get installed there by default , which is annoying when dealing with multiple installation of python 2.7.

Only a small amount of issues in anaconda's github tracker anaconda-issues get feedback, even less are resolved - even the simpler ones, that e.g. only require a simple rebuild of certain packages. As a consequence some of the packages in the recent stable release seem to be broken and it seems that there is little interest in fixing that.
Are you planning to improve that in future? Being forced to stitch conda and pip together with a lot of workarounds to counter broken packages is starting to make the conda experience very frustrating for me.
text:

As a consequence some of the packages in the recent stable release seem to be broken and it seems that there is little interest in fixing that. 
Are you planning to improve that in future? Being forced to stitch conda and pip together with a lot of workarounds to counter broken packages is starting to make the conda experience very frustrating for me.

html:
@groutr - it just disables the sys.path mangling:
  • update to 18.3:
    • Setuptools now allows disabling of the manipulation of the sys.path
      during the processing of the easy-install.pth file. To do so, set
      the environment variable SETUPTOOLS_SYS_PATH_TECHNIQUE to
      anything but "rewrite" (consider "raw"). During any install operation
      with manipulation disabled, setuptools packages will be appended to
      sys.path naturally.
text:
@groutr - it just disables the sys.path mangling:
> - update to 18.3:
  * Setuptools now allows disabling of the manipulation of the sys.path
    during the processing of the easy-install.pth file. To do so, set
    the environment variable ``SETUPTOOLS_SYS_PATH_TECHNIQUE`` to
    anything but "rewrite" (consider "raw"). During any install operation
    with manipulation disabled, setuptools packages will be appended to
    sys.path naturally.

html: Hello. Jason Moore @moorepants has tried to convince me to use conda to distribute my lab's C++ software. I've been kinda skeptical. However, I really like a lot of conda, so I'd like to ask a few questions
text: Hello. Jason Moore @moorepants has tried to convince me to use conda to distribute my lab's C++ software. I've been kinda skeptical. However, I really like a lot of conda, so I'd like to ask a few questions

html: Hi @chrisdembia . What questions do you have?
text: Hi @chrisdembia .  What questions do you have?

html: First off, conda is well-suited to our project, because we use multiple languages in the project (C++, python, java, matlab), so I agree with the idea of a multilingual package manager
text: First off, conda is well-suited to our project, because we use multiple languages in the project (C++, python, java, matlab), so I agree with the idea of a multilingual package manager

html: The things holding me back are: (1) conda is not yet too popular for C++, so I'd have to tell users to download/install conda first; (2) it's not clear how much of a priority languages other than python are for conda, (3) conda's branding is kinda confusing; it doesn't exactly feel like an independent project. I feel that if I told someone to get conda, they'd get confused by the fact that they need to get "miniconda"
text: The things holding me back are: (1) conda is not yet too popular for C++, so I'd have to tell users to download/install conda first; (2) it's not clear how much of a priority languages other than python are for conda, (3) conda's branding is kinda confusing; it doesn't exactly feel like an independent project. I feel that if I told someone to get conda, they'd get confused by the fact that they need to get "miniconda"

html: hmm...so I guess those aren't exactly questions
text: hmm...so I guess those aren't exactly questions

html: I guess...have you heard of any similar concerns? How strong do you think C++ support is now?
text: I guess...have you heard of any similar concerns? How strong do you think C++ support is now?

html: What methods of distribution are you considering?
text: What methods of distribution are you considering?

html: well we distribute standalone binaries/installers for our software for users, so I'm mainly thinking about developers
text: well we distribute standalone binaries/installers for our software for users, so I'm mainly thinking about developers

html: conda itself is pretty language agnostic.  We build and distribute lots of C/C++ libraries with conda in the official repos.
text: conda itself is pretty language agnostic.  We build and distribute lots of C/C++ libraries with conda in the official repos.

html: who need to build our project from source
text: who need to build our project from source

html: 2) conda manages files.  It doesn’t know what those files are.  Recipes are written using bash (unix) or batch scripts (windows).
text: 2) conda manages files.  It doesn’t know what those files are.  Recipes are written using bash (unix) or batch scripts (windows).

html: I still feel iffy about "conda vs miniconda". I feel that if I tell people who don't know anything about python or Anaconda to download conda, they might feel like "well now what's this miniconda thing?"
text: I still feel iffy about "conda vs miniconda". I feel that if I tell people who don't know anything about python or Anaconda to download conda, they might feel like "well now what's this miniconda thing?"

text: In response to (2), yes, but there are things like debug/release configurations, C++11 compatibility, etc to think about with C++

text: Conda has a longer history in the Python world.  But is seems to be gaining traction elsewhere in scientific community as well (particuarly R).

html: That's definitely good to hear. I would like for conda to be successful; it seems very promising to me.
text: That's definitely good to hear. I would like for conda to be successful; it seems very promising to me.

html: 3) miniconda is essentially conda + a minimal python install (which is a dependency of conda).
text: 3) miniconda is essentially conda + a minimal python install (which is a dependency of conda).

text: My sense is that distributing "conda" on its own, or branding it that way, would help. For example, it doesn't need to be marketed that conda includes a python distribution, since non-python users don't care about that

html: Then, instead of "miniconda = python + conda", the picture to non-python people would be "conda = package manager (with python inside)"
text: Then, instead of "miniconda = python + conda", the picture to non-python people would be "conda = package manager (with python inside)"

text: Conda can also be installed as a python package.  Though, the most tested way (and probably more reliable way) of getting conda is using the bundled python.

text: Yeah, no problem.  Thanks for the suggestions.

text: I didn't know that. I myself use python, but I'm trying to think from the perspective of someone who has never used Python.

text: That is a very valuable exercise.

html: The last thing I want to mention is about the default install location of conda (well, miniconda, anaconda). I really like that mini/anaconda are self-contained in one directory; this is REALLY nice.
text: The last thing I want to mention is about the default install location of conda (well, miniconda, anaconda). I *really* like that mini/anaconda are self-contained in one directory; this is REALLY nice.

html: I can see how the python messaging might be a little troubling for somebody who is thinking of using conda outside of python.
text: I can see how the python messaging might be a little troubling for somebody who is thinking of using conda outside of python.

html: I believe that the install location was a specific design decision.  It allows unpriviledged users to more easy use conda.
text: I believe that the install location was a specific design decision.  It allows unpriviledged users to more easy use conda.

html: Yeah, like the feeling I have is that conda could be implemented in any language
text: Yeah, like the feeling I have is that conda *could* be implemented in any language

text: It could be, albeit with quite a bit work.

html: Oh I'm definitely not suggesting it should be in another language, my point is just that since it could be in any language, there's no need to reveal that it is written in python
text: Oh I'm definitely not suggesting it should be in another language, my point is just that since it could be in any language, there's no need to reveal that it is written in python

html: As for the install directory, that's a good point. In that case, on OSX, another possibility would be to default to ~/Applications, though that would then cause the default install directory to be inconsistent across platforms.
text: As for the install directory, that's a good point. In that case, on OSX, another possibility would be to default to ~/Applications, though that would then cause the default install directory to be inconsistent across platforms.

html: I still feel that a mainstream app should be installed into the OS-dependent canonical directories, so perhaps, down the line, there could be alternative ways of installing conda: "as a regular app", and as "non-priviledged users"
text: I still feel that a mainstream app should be installed into the OS-dependent canonical directories, so perhaps, down the line, there could be alternative ways of installing conda: "as a regular app", and as "non-priviledged users"

html: Anyway, great tool. I love the idea of virtual environments extending beyond python

text: Some more developments on the headers thing, and why the distutils example did work.

html: So with setuptools, python setup.py installdoes not install headers
text: So with setuptools, `python setup.py install`does *not* install headers

html: But when using pip, there is an additional flag -single-version-externally-managedthat makes it a "normal" install and headers get installed
text: But when using pip, there is an additional flag `-single-version-externally-managed`that makes it a "normal" install and headers get installed

html: On the other side, we cannot make a wheel with distutils.

html:
@groutr has posted builds of my improved dependency resolve to his anaconda.org channel, making it easy for people to bang on this before we officially release it:

conda install -c https://conda.anaconda.org/rgrout conda

If you have some conda install or conda update scenarios that are particularly slow with the current solver or produce unexpected results, you might want to try this. Feel free to open issues if you find them.
text:
@groutr has posted builds of my improved dependency resolve to his anaconda.org channel, making it easy for people to bang on this before we officially release it:
```
conda install -c https://conda.anaconda.org/rgrout conda
```
If you have some `conda install` or `conda update` scenarios that are particularly slow with the current solver or produce unexpected results, you might want to try this. Feel free to open issues if you find them.

text: it seems that conda has issues forming a valid package version number from the git describe tag when using a commit that is not a tag

html: So, that isn't actually a conda problem. It is just how git describe works. I'll send you a snippet that does a PEP440 style version string in a conda recipe in a sec.
text: So, that isn't actually a conda problem. It is just how `git describe` works. I'll send you a snippet that does a PEP440 style version string in a conda recipe in a sec.

html: This works for me.
text: This works for me.

html: {{ environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_TAG', '')[1:] }}{{ '+' + environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_NUMBER', '0') + '.' + environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_HASH', '0') if environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_NUMBER', '0') != '0' else "" }}
text: {{ environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_TAG', '')[1:] }}{{ '+' + environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_NUMBER', '0') + '.' + environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_HASH', '0') if environ.get('GIT_DESCRIBE_NUMBER', '0') != '0' else "" }}

html: Something else to consider is using versioneer to create your version info based on git describe in setup.py and then write it to the __conda_version__.txt at build time. The former (jinja solution) is good for having a simple solution that you can use with conda. The latter (versioneer) is good if you are definitely using python and plan on using git-based versioning for your python packaging, as well, and don't mind having an extra line for each platform's build recipe.
text: Something else to consider is using [`versioneer`]( https://github.com/warner/python-versioneer ) to create your version info based on `git describe` in `setup.py` and then write it to the `__conda_version__.txt` at build time. The former (jinja solution) is good for having a simple solution that you can use with conda. The latter (versioneer) is good if you are definitely using python and plan on using git-based versioning for your python packaging, as well, and don't mind having an extra line for each platform's build recipe.

Hey guys, I have a problem: I'm installing new environment with conda from .yml file (yml is essntial - I am using third-party channel)

I need to be able to have two identical environments, one with python2, one with python3.

  • I can create separately both with only python installed, but I can't install from .yml in these envs (only txt)
  • I can conda create env, but I can't specify version of python to install.
  • In ideal world, I'd like not to create separate copy of each library for each of environments, but this is bearable.

So far I know ugly, but working solution: create two identical .yml and add there two versions of python. Someone knows better way?
text:
Hey guys, I have a problem: I'm installing new environment with conda from `.yml` file (yml is essntial - I am using  third-party channel)

I need to be able to have two identical environments, one with python2, one with python3.

- I can create separately both with only python installed, but I can't install from .yml in these envs (only txt)
- I can `conda create env`, but I can't specify version of python to install.
- In ideal world, I'd like not to create separate copy of each library for each of environments, but this is bearable.

So far I know ugly, but working solution: create two identical .yml and add there two versions of python. Someone knows better way?

html: You could run an install command afterwards to select the version of Python. This will change all the packages in the environment to match that version.
text: You could run an install command afterwards to select the version of Python. This will change all the packages in the environment to match that version.

html: Here is the "rule of thumb". If it is pure Python, you are fine. If it is Python using cffi, you should be fine (running the tests in different environments will help). If you have C/C++ code that doesn't include Python.h or doesn't use Boost.Python, it shouldn't depend on Python and should be fine (again testing helps). If it has Cython, it will not work. Checking linkages using ldd will help clear up anything that is not obvious. More simply running conda inspect linkages on existing conda packages will show this information for the package and any dependencies. If either shows libpython*.so in the linkages, you know it is Python dependent.
text: Here is the "rule of thumb". If it is pure Python, you are fine. If it is Python using `cffi`, you *should* be fine (running the tests in different environments will help). If you have C/C++ code that doesn't include `Python.h` or doesn't use `Boost.Python`, it shouldn't depend on Python and should be fine (again testing helps). If it has Cython, it will not work. Checking linkages using `ldd` will help clear up anything that is not obvious. More simply running `conda inspect linkages` on existing conda packages will show this information for the package and any dependencies. If either shows `libpython*.so` in the linkages, you know it is Python dependent.

html: a related features question: the presence of a feature in an environment just gives preference to a package variant, right? i.e., for a given package, it prefers a variant having the feature over one that doesn't. How would that work for exclusion, @jakirkham? if I excluded the mkl, I might expect that I will never have a package with an mkl feature, but you might also say that's not the opposite meaning of the inclusion (which is a preference, not a hard constraint). Or do you imagine an exclusion being just a preference for packages without the feature, but it would install a package with the feature if that was the only one found?

html: I can't say I know all the history here. But previously the solver was a very expensive operation. I guess it was decided that it should not be invoked during remove at all, and that its scope should be limited during update or install commands, in order to ensure it wasn't overwhelmed. But that came with the cost: breaking people's environments.
text: I can't say I know all the history here. But previously the solver was a very expensive operation. I guess it was decided that it should not be invoked during `remove` at all, and that its scope should be limited during `update` or `install` commands, in order to ensure it wasn't overwhelmed. But that came with the cost: breaking people's environments.

@ijstokes, what you're asking for is akin to something we have talked about calling conda repair or conda doctor, and it's not available yet. The solver would be tasked with finding the largest subset of the currently installed packages that could be made consistent through version adjustments alone.

I actually had this functionality in there already but we pulled it because it just seemed too aggressive to do automatically. But we agreed it needed to be added as a command.
text:
@ijstokes, what you're asking for is akin to something we have talked about calling `conda repair` or `conda doctor`, and it's not available yet. @SylvainCorlay So, not actually working for Continuum I can only muse on this point, but my understanding is CPython itself will is only built with a certain version of the MSVC runtime. ( https://wiki.python.org/moin/WindowsCompilers ) Continuum is merely following those guidelines. I don't think they will (though someone who knows more is welcome to correct me) support a version of the MSVC runtime with a version of CPython that is not supported by CPython itself.

That being said, I know people have successfully compiled versions of CPython with unsupported (most often newer) versions the MSVC runtime and have whole stacks that are built this way to say leverage C++11 features for instance.

The only case I know of with a sizeable stack of this sort in conda would be the truly impressive work of @ukoethe (don't think he is on gitter), which can be seen on this branch of this repo. ( https://github.com/ilastik/ilastik-build-conda/tree/toolset-config ) Though the easiest solution may be just to leverage his stack through his channel ( https://anaconda.org/ukoethe ) and just build the one or two other things you need.

@jakirkham it is actually ok to build c extension with other versions of MSVC than the one used to build python as soon as all the objects that are passed to or received from python are allocated / freed with the same C runtime as the one used by the python interpreter.
text: @jakirkham it is actually ok to build c extension with other versions of MSVC than the one used to build python as soon as all the objects that are passed to or received from python are allocated / freed with the same C runtime as the one used by the python interpreter.

text:
Hi, I am new to ``conda``. I try to understand what's a difference between exporting the environment with
```
conda env export
```
and 
```
conda list -e
```

The only difference I noticed so far is
* first one is ``yaml`` format
* second doesn't contain information about pip-installed packages

Are there any other significant differences?

html:
The current thinking with features is they should be put in meta packages.

For your nox @minrk, one might do something like make a uses_vtk meta package that has uses_vtk in its track_features. Then you could have a nox package built without vtk and a nox_uses_vtk package that is built with vtk and includes the feature uses_vtk. This way you can always install nox, but if you install use_vtk the nox version that is linked against vtk will also be installed.

More details here ( http://conda.pydata.org/docs/building/meta-yaml.html#id1 ).
text:
The current thinking with features is they should be put in meta packages.

For your `nox` @minrk, one might do something like make a `uses_vtk` meta package that has `uses_vtk` in its `track_features`. Then you could have a `nox` package built without `vtk` and a `nox_uses_vtk` package that is built with `vtk` and includes the `feature` `uses_vtk`. This way you can always install `nox`, but if you install `use_vtk` the `nox` version that is linked against `vtk` will also be installed.

More details here ( http://conda.pydata.org/docs/building/meta-yaml.html#id1 ).

text: I wouldn't say it is completely different, no---from the perspective of conda's solver there are a lot of important similarities. Forcing someone to remove the anaconda metapackage even to make the most minor changes is psychologically undesirable. At the same time I do think it's important to let people know that they are deviating from the version grid, and the anaconda-custom package does that.

More explicit messaging may be warranted, but I don't want to clutter the conda code with Anaconda-specific messaging. Besides, anaconda is not the only "package collection" metapackage out there, or at least, it doesn't need to be. This -custom idiom is something that anyone can do if they're building and maintaining package sets.
text:
Forcing someone to remove the `anaconda` metapackage even to make the most minor changes is psychologically undesirable. At the same time I do think it's important to let people know that they are deviating from the version grid, and the `anaconda-custom` package does  that. 

More explicit messaging may be warranted, but I don't want to clutter the `conda` code with Anaconda-specific messaging. Besides, `anaconda` is not the only "package collection" metapackage out there, or at least, it doesn't need to be. This `-custom` idiom is something that anyone can do if they're building and maintaining package sets.

html: I'm interested in the topic since at my previous company we used a metapackage with exact versions, including build strings to create an exactly reproducible environment which worked very well for us. It was very common however for front-office developers/analysts to update specific packages and in fact it used to be the case that updating any package would update all dependencies which often caused some issues with e.g. pandas.
text: I'm interested in the topic since at my previous company we used a metapackage with exact versions, including build strings to create an exactly reproducible environment which worked very well for us. It was very common however for front-office developers/analysts to update specific packages and in fact it used to be the case that updating any package would update *all* dependencies which often caused some issues with e.g. pandas.

html: That solution predated the environment.yml concept though so I'm wondering if that would be a better route to go down (to create exactly reproducible environments) if I were starting from scratch
text: That solution predated the `environment.yml` concept though so I'm wondering if that would be a better route to go down (to create exactly reproducible environments) if I were starting from scratch

html: A couple of things. First, older versions of conda already allowed people to update individual packages in the Anaconda distribution, but it did so for the wrong reasons: it did so because it just didn't do a full dependency solve with every install and update. My assumption is that this was for performance reasons. But the end result was that people got used to being able to, say, install Anaconda and then update Pandas separately. They also got used to breaking their environments unintentionally.
text: A couple of things. First, older versions of conda already allowed people to update individual packages in the Anaconda distribution, but it did so for the wrong reasons: it did so because it just didn't do a full dependency solve with every install and update. My assumption is that this was for performance reasons. But the end result was that people got used to being able to, say, install Anaconda and then update Pandas separately. They also got used to breaking their environments unintentionally.

html:
With the newer, strict solver, on the other hand---and before we introduced the -custom Anaconda package, this wouldn't do what you want:

conda create -n test anaconda
conda update -n test pandas

That is, conda would not give you the latest version of Pandas, because anaconda locked it down to an earlier version.

And it's a bit worse than that, actually. One thing conda is still weak about is explaining why it arrived at the solution it did. But when you try the above (before the existence of the -custom package), conda would just tell you that you already have the latest version. Well, the truth is that you just have the latest version compatible with your dependencies. But that's not quite the same thing, and it confuses people who know that a new version of Pandas has been uploaded.

So we still need to improve the messaging, but we also wanted to give people a user experience they're accustomed to.

Now, if you wanted to create a metapackage that pins packages to particular versions, you can---and if you don't create the -custom version like we've done for Anaconda, it will prevent users from updating individual packages.
text:
With the newer, strict solver, on the other hand---and before we introduced the `-custom` Anaconda package, this wouldn't do what you want:
```
conda create -n test anaconda
conda update -n test pandas
```
That is, conda would _not_ give you the latest version of Pandas, because `anaconda` locked it down to an earlier version.

And it's a bit worse than that, actually. One thing `conda` is still weak about is explaining *why* it arrived at the solution it did. But when you try the above (before the existence of the `-custom` package), `conda` would just tell you _that you already have the latest version._ Well, the truth is that you just have the latest version compatible with your dependencies. But that's not quite the same thing, and it confuses people who know that a new version of Pandas has been uploaded.

So we still need to improve the messaging, but we also wanted to give people a user experience they're accustomed to.

Now, if you wanted to create a metapackage that pins packages to particular versions, you can---and if you don't create the `-custom` version like we've done for Anaconda, it _will_ prevent users from updating individual packages.

I just want to make sure we're not talking past each other. We've found a solution to our problem with Anaconda: users can now install anaconda, and then update or even remove packages. If that's what you want to do, I suggest you consider our -custom version approach.

If you want to prevent people from tweaking individual packages, then you'll want a metapackage that doesn't have a -custom version. Then you get the full benefits of the strict solver to help lock you down.

I don't know enough about environment.yml to answer that one.
text:
I just want to make sure we're not talking past each other. We've found a solution to our problem with Anaconda: users can now install anaconda, and then update or even _remove_ packages. If that's what you want to do, I suggest you consider our `-custom` version approach.

If you want to prevent people from tweaking individual packages, then you'll want a metapackage that _doesn't_ have a `-custom` version. Then you get the full benefits of the strict solver to help lock you down.

I don't know enough about `environment.yml` to answer that one.

html: What is the -custom version approach? First I've heard of it, but we may have to implement something similar (or go down the environment.yml route)
text: What *is* the `-custom` version approach? First I've heard of it, but we may have to implement something similar (or go down the environment.yml route)

html:
So it turns out that if you give a package a version number of custom, it sorts earlier than any numeric version of the same package.

What we did was create packages like anaconda-custom-py27_0.tar.bz2. This is now considered the "oldest" version of Anaconda on the repository. It has exactly one dependency: python 2.7*. The reason we gave it any dependencies is that anaconda is not actually an empty package: it has a file that is used to modify the Python command prompt. Try installing Anaconda, run python, then remove anaconda, and run python again.

So what happens is this: when someone tries to update an individual package within the Anaconda environment, the solver decides it has to DOWNGRADE anaconda to version custom. Every other package can remain right where it is. But this frees up the version grid, and the user can make further customizations to his environment.

What's key is that anaconda itself is still there, so doing something like conda update anaconda snaps them back to the version grid.
text:
So it turns  out that if you give a package a version number of `custom`, it sorts earlier than any numeric version of the same package.

What we did was create packages like `anaconda-custom-py27_0.tar.bz2`. This is now considered the "oldest" version of Anaconda on the repository. It has exactly one dependency: `python 2.7*`. The reason we gave it _any_ dependencies is that `anaconda` is not actually an empty package: it has a file that is used to modify the Python command prompt. Try installing Anaconda, run `python`, then remove `anaconda`, and run `python` again.

So what happens is this: when someone tries to update an individual package within the Anaconda environment, the solver decides it has to DOWNGRADE `anaconda` to version `custom`. Every other package can remain right where it is. But this frees up the version grid, and the user can make further customizations to his environment.

What's key is that `anaconda` itself is still there, so doing something like `conda update anaconda` snaps them back to the version grid.

html:
@groutr the crux of the nbextension problem is the following: the python packages including notebook extensions can do two more things.

  1. install nbextension (putting javascript asset files in the right place)
    jupyter nbextension install --py foobar
  2. enable extension (edit a json file which indexes the extensions to load)
    jupyter nbextension enable --py foobar

Details:

  • The first part can put the assets a variety of directories that will be picked up by the notebook server. Thankfully, one of them is under sys.prefix. In ipywidgets, in a non-dev install we can skip that step because we use the wheel's data_file thing and it is picked up by the conda-build

  • For the second part, the edited file can be found in multiple configuration (/usr/local, ~/.local, and one under sys prefix) and the notebook server will merge all the nbextension it find.
text:
@groutr the crux of the nbextension problem is the following: the python packages including notebook extensions can do two more things.
1. install nbextension (putting javascript asset files in the right place)
    `jupyter nbextension install --py foobar`
2. enable extension (edit a json file which indexes the extensions to load)
     `jupyter nbextension enable --py foobar`

Details:
- The first part can put the assets a variety of  directories that will be picked up by the notebook server. Thankfully, one of them is under `sys.prefix`. In ipywidgets, in a non-dev install we can skip that step because we use the wheel's `data_file` thing and it is picked up by the  conda-build

- For the second part, the edited file can be found in multiple configuration (/usr/local, ~/.local, and one under sys prefix) and the notebook server will merge all the nbextension it find.

html: The big problem IMO is the second part, which, even with the --sys-prefix argument, does more than adding files. It edits a configuration file.
text: The big problem IMO is the second part, which, even with the `--sys-prefix` argument, does more than adding files. It *edits* a configuration file.

html: If instead of editing a file, we add a directory like init.d where notebook extensions could put some metadata, we would be fine.
text: If instead of editing a file, we add a directory like `init.d` where notebook extensions could put some metadata, we would be fine.

html:
@/all, specially @SylvainCorlay @jasongrout, @groutr, more info about this: notebook 4.2 brings a new mechanism to install and enable nbextension and serverextension not only on the "user" space but also in other spaces, such as prefix which is important for conda, to be able to install extension on the prefix instead of "globally".
The conf.d approach is something we are discussing but it is not part of the notebook 4.2 release, it was something too big for that and we need more discussion and implementation.
Then, in notebook 4.2, we install and enable our (continuum) extension using post-script steps. You can see the one example here: https://github.com/Anaconda-Platform/nb_conda/blob/master/conda.recipe/post-link.sh
And we will have that extension in repo.cio, BUT for the next anaconda release, since the post-script mechanism is something prone to generate issues from the Anaconda side, we are enabling this extension using a metapackage which essentially provides the proper json file: https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-nb-extensions-meta-config/blob/master/meta.yaml.
When the conf.d approach is developed, we are going to migrate to that mechanism, but there is still work to do on the path...
I hope this helps to understand the current situation :wink:
text:
@/all, specially @SylvainCorlay @jasongrout, @groutr, more info about this: notebook 4.2 brings a new mechanism to install and enable nbextension and serverextension not only on the "user" space but also in other spaces, such as `prefix` which is important for conda, to be able to install extension on the prefix instead of "globally".
The conf.d approach is something we are discussing but it is not part of the notebook 4.2 release, it was something too big for that and we need more discussion and implementation.
Then, in notebook 4.2, we install and enable our (continuum) extension using post-script steps. You can see the one example here: https://github.com/Anaconda-Platform/nb_conda/blob/master/conda.recipe/post-link.sh
And we will have that extension in repo.cio, BUT for the next anaconda release, since the post-script mechanism is something prone to generate issues from the Anaconda side, we are enabling this extension using a metapackage which essentially provides the proper json file: https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-nb-extensions-meta-config/blob/master/meta.yaml.
When the conf.d approach is developed, we are going to migrate to that mechanism, but there is still work to do on the path...
I hope this helps to understand the current situation :wink:

Damian and Nick (who I think you know) are leading the charge with getting this bundle of extensions prepared for Anaconda 4.1 (June/early-July time-frame) inclusion. They aren't on this Gitter room, so you might want to follow up with them externally.

html: • it seems that a build dependency of a build dependency is not a build dependency.
text: - it seems that a build dependency of a build dependency is not a build dependency.

html: If two packages (P1 and P2) only exposes headers (via distutils.install_headers command) and P2 includes headers from P1, should P1 be a build or runtime dep of P2.
text: If two packages (P1 and P2) only exposes headers (via distutils.install_headers command) and P2 includes headers from P1, should P1 be a build or runtime dep of P2.

html: I initially thought the former (build dep).
text: I initially thought the former (build dep).

html: But now if you have P3 that includes headers from P2 which in turn includes headers from P1, these headers will be missing at build time for P3.
text: But now if you have P3 that includes headers from P2 which in turn includes headers from P1, these headers will be missing at build time for P3.

html: It seems like it is a bug.
text: It seems like it is a bug.

html: @SylvainCorlay I think that means you have a build dependency on P1 and should declare it as such. I'm not sure it's a universal thing that projects will include headers from another project than then includes headers from yet another project. Usually you just include headers that only include stuff inside the project itself or in standard libraries.
text: @SylvainCorlay I think that means you have a build dependency on P1 and should declare it as such. I'm sure this has come up before, but my google-fu is failing me. Is there an example of the best pattern for the case in which a library can be freely downloaded but not redistributed on its own?

So a conda package in which (for example) build.sh calls python which downloads the binaries from their URLs and then installs them would be fine (because then the recipe is just a glorified set of instructions), but one which actually includes the binary itself would not. For all I know though there's a yaml section which means "download these files but do nothing with them", which would be a little cleaner.
text:
I'm sure this has come up before, but my google-fu is failing me.  Is there an example of the best pattern for the case in which a library can be freely downloaded but not redistributed on its own?

So a conda package in which (for example) build.sh calls python which downloads the binaries from their URLs and then installs them would be fine (because then the recipe is just a glorified set of instructions), but one which actually includes the binary itself would not.   For all I know though there's a yaml section which means "download these files but do nothing with them", which would be a little cleaner.

html: @damianavila do you have any info on this?
text: @damianavila do you have any info on this?

html: @SylvainCorlay, the situation is the following: other extensions like nbpresent + others have been included in the Anaconda distro sacrificing the post-scripts step (with a not so nice workaround). The Anaconda team is worried about side effect of postscripts, so they are not allowing packages with post-scripts into the distro. The Anaconda team is waiting for the conf.d based approach to include packages like ipywidgets. One alternative would be to have ipywidgets installed with the current mechanism for the other nbextensions already present but they will be bundled together (maybe not the best experience, but at least we have it there). I can try to push to get something like that... but at the end depends on the Anaconda team.
text: @SylvainCorlay, the situation is the following: other extensions like nbpresent + others have been included in the Anaconda distro sacrificing the post-scripts step (with a not so nice workaround). The Anaconda team is worried about side effect of postscripts, so they are not allowing packages with post-scripts into the distro. The Anaconda team is waiting for the conf.d based approach to include packages like ipywidgets. One alternative would be to have ipywidgets installed with the current mechanism for the other nbextensions already present but they will be bundled together (maybe not the best experience, but at least we have it there). I can try to push to get something like that... but at the end depends on the Anaconda team.

html: Well, the thing is that this is not what I was told initially and sort of contradicted by the fact that nbpresent is there... Besides, unlike most nbextensions, ipywidgets is a dependency  of many others, and activation does not activate dependencies.
text: Well, the thing is that this is not what I was told initially and sort of contradicted by the fact that nbpresent is there... Besides, unlike most nbextensions, ipywidgets is a dependency  of many others, and activation does not activate dependencies.

html: I am find this very discouraging. Especially since I recall that the current extension mechanism was developed at the initiative of continuum folks for integration with conda.

html: I find the current nbextension mechanism terrible - but we have to live with it at least for some time. Pinning core jupyter packages to year-old versions is not helping.
text: I find the current nbextension mechanism terrible - but we have to live with it at least for some time. Pinning core jupyter packages to year-old versions is *not* helping.

html:
I understand your feelings... as you said the current extension mechanism was developed to take into account conda... but not Anaconda... that is the main issue. Currently the best possible path from my point of view is try to make the nbextension mechanism better, if we can put a conf.d based mechanism in place quickly (it should not be comprehensive, it could be a partial thing), then we can sort out this issue.
The discussion about the integration of ipywigets in Anaconda happened but I will rise the issue again.
From the Jupyter side, I think we need to push forward on a based conf.d mechanism. I will try to work on that a little bit this /next week. In fact there is an open PR from Min in the trailets repo.
text:
I understand your feelings... as you said the current extension mechanism was developed to take into account conda... but not Anaconda... that is the main issue. Currently the best possible path from my point of view is try to make the nbextension mechanism better, if we can put a conf.d based mechanism in place quickly (it should not be comprehensive, it could be a partial thing), then we can sort out this issue.
The discussion about the integration of ipywigets in Anaconda happened but I will rise the issue again. 
From the Jupyter side, I think we need to push forward on a based conf.d mechanism. I will try to work on that a little bit this /next week. In fact there is an open PR from Min in the trailets repo.

html: And as I said, the nbpresent version there does not contains any post-script, but it is installed along with the other extensions and you can not install/uninstall per extension, you install/uninstall all the bundle, in fact, I am not sure if adding ipywidgets into that bundle would be OK since it will get uninstalled if people uninstall any of the other extensions... at the end, not a great situation... this is why I think we need to push forward on the conf.d mechanism, at least, a partial one.

html: @pmlandwehr - install conda build >= 1.21.11. The issue was that conda-build created a root logger, and conda imported it at startup, which led to conda's logger messages being always shown.
text: @pmlandwehr - install conda build >= 1.21.11.  The issue was that conda-build created a root logger, and conda imported it at startup, which led to conda's logger messages being always shown.

html: conda-build 1.21.11 moved its root logger from init.py to several similar root loggers - one per entry point.
text: conda-build 1.21.11 moved its root logger from __init__.py to several similar root loggers - one per entry point.

I see that @kalefranz  has packaged mysql-server-5.5 but it's not clear to me how the service is actually managed (in terms of starting it etc)

html: AFAICT it doesn't install any upstart/sysvinit/systemd scripts (and perhaps maybe it should not). Should I abandon trying to have services like this managed in Conda, or am I doing it wrong ?

html: @JohnGreeley, yes I know the status. conda/conda-recipes is marked as deprecated but I still do my R work in there. conda-forge do not have R packages at present. Make your pull requests against conda/conda-recipes for now. Until conda-forge and conda's defaults channel are binary compatible, we cannot shift the R recipes to conda-forge.

html: @JohnGreeley We're considering options there, we expect to continue support until a few months after EOL to give people time to migrate. It might be possible that we offer longer-term legacy support if there's enough (paid) interest to make it worthwhile for us, maybe for enterprise customers, we're unclear how to proceed at present and need better package building infrastructure before we'll be able to make a decision.

html:
Hi all,

I'm the author/maintainer of the spaCy NLP library. Previously the project had someone taking care of conda builds and wheels, but they've no longer involved with the project. I'm trying to figure out what the best process is to ship the different release artefacts needed for conda and wheel support, while also making sure I can release quickly.

It seems like ideally we'd like to have artefacts up for all of the following: {wheel, sdist}, {64bit, 32bit}, {OSX, Linux, Windows}, {2.7, 3.5, 3.6}, {conda, pip}. By my count this is 22332=64 artefacts on every release. I'd like to be releasing about every two weeks. This seems tough!

How are other people doing this?
text:
Hi all,

I'm the author/maintainer of the spaCy NLP library. Previously the project had someone taking care of conda builds and wheels, but they've no longer involved with the project. I'm trying to figure out what the best process is to ship the different release artefacts needed for conda and wheel support, while also making sure I can release quickly.

It seems like ideally we'd like to have artefacts up for all of the following: {wheel, sdist}, {64bit, 32bit}, {OSX, Linux, Windows}, {2.7, 3.5, 3.6}, {conda, pip}. By my count this is 2*2*3*3*2=64 artefacts on every release. I'd like to be releasing about every two weeks. This seems tough!

How are other people doing this?

html:
1. open a PR to staged-recipes repo following the example recipe
  2. When it is merged, the first version of your package is uploaded to conda-forge and a new "feedstock" repo is created in the organization.
  3. Further releases are made by opening PRs to your feedstock.
text:
1. open a PR to staged-recipes repo following the example recipe
2. When it is merged, the first version of your package is uploaded to conda-forge and a new "feedstock" repo is created in the organization. 
3. Further releases are made by opening PRs to your feedstock.

text: That would be a pretty useful function to have but I'm not sure it exists. You can use `--reverse-dependency` to search for packages which depend on a certain package but it't not tied to the environment AFAIK.

html:
The below very ugly hack may work in a pinch:
In [40]: dep_pkgs = !conda search --reverse-dependency --json tqdm
    ...: env_pkgs = !conda list --json

In [41]: dep_pkgs = set(json.loads('\n'.join(dep_pkgs)).keys())
    ...: dep_pkgs
Out[41]: {'gala', 'hyperspy', 'pycalphad', 'pymc3', 'statuspage', 'tpot'}

In [42]: env_pkgs = {
    ...:     '-'.join(pkg.split('::')[-1].split('-')[:-2])
    ...:      for pkg in json.loads('\n'.join(env_pkgs))
    ...: }

In [43]: env_pkgs.intersection(dep_pkgs)
Out[43]: {'pymc3'}
text:
The below *very* ugly hack may work in a pinch:
```python
In [40]: dep_pkgs = !conda search --reverse-dependency --json tqdm
    ...: env_pkgs = !conda list --json

In [41]: dep_pkgs = set(json.loads('\n'.join(dep_pkgs)).keys())
    ...: dep_pkgs
Out[41]: {'gala', 'hyperspy', 'pycalphad', 'pymc3', 'statuspage', 'tpot'}

In [42]: env_pkgs = {
    ...:     '-'.join(pkg.split('::')[-1].split('-')[:-2])
    ...:      for pkg in json.loads('\n'.join(env_pkgs))
    ...: }

In [43]: env_pkgs.intersection(dep_pkgs)
Out[43]: {'pymc3'}
```

conda seems to have some random failures where it installs the wrong version, known things I have seen:
  • currently for the xz package: Instead of downloading the linux-64 version, it downloads the osx-64 version from the noarch channel. On top of that, it actually checks it with the md5 checksum of the linux-64 version. ( conda/conda#4642 )
  • when installing redis-py it will require redis, this works fine, unless you install at the same time a package from a different channel (environment.yaml file), which also includes a package called redis. In that case it will install the incompatible version from the other channel
text:
conda seems to have some random failures where it installs the wrong version, known things I have seen:
- currently for the xz package: Instead of downloading the linux-64 version, it downloads the osx-64 version from the noarch channel. On top of that, it actually checks it with the md5 checksum of the linux-64 version. ( https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/4642 )
- when installing redis-py it will require redis, this works fine, unless you install at the same time a package from a different channel (environment.yaml file), which also includes a package called redis. In that case it will install the incompatible version from the other channel

text: Hello!! Which is the best way to creating a fully self-contained Python package. I am wondering if to use conda environments is a good idea. Are they relocatable or only reproducible? Can I packaging up a portable application with conda? Should I use a python builder or something like that?  I have just change the location of my conda environment and it seems that is working well. And I am not activating it with source activate environment, instead of that I am just running my application with the python file which is in the bin folder of the environment. Do you think this is going to bring me problems in the future or that is enough to make me application work?

html: @ChesuCR_twitter in general, conda environments are not relocatable. They are designed to be reproducible, provided the required packages have been built for the target platform.
text: @ChesuCR_twitter in general, conda environments are not relocatable.  They are designed to be reproducible, provided the required packages have been built for the target platform.

html:
@SylvainCorlay yes, @mingwandroid and I have spent a lot of time on gcc. Ray's latest work is at https://github.com/conda/conda-recipes/tree/master/cross-compilers/compilers_generic

Both Ray and I have compiler packages that you can test. Look for things like gcc_linux-cos5-x86_64. Note that these packages are much more split up that the older gcc packages. g++ is a separate package (gxx_linux-cos5-x86_64) as is gfortran.
text:
@SylvainCorlay yes, @mingwandroid and I have spent a lot of time on gcc.  Ray's latest work is at https://github.com/conda/conda-recipes/tree/master/cross-compilers/compilers_generic

Both Ray and I have compiler packages that you can test.  Look for things like gcc_linux-cos5-x86_64.  Note that these packages are much more split up that the older gcc packages.  g++ is a separate package (gxx_linux-cos5-x86_64) as is gfortran.

html: @msarahan this is great news. In my tests with the salford system recipe, when I build everything with it and ship the libc of gcc-6 as a runtime dependency to my packages, cling works beautifully. They have much stronger requirements in terms of libc compatibility than a regular package because the interpreted code must use the exact same libc than the compiled code of the interpreter...
text: @msarahan this is great news. In my tests with the salford system recipe, when I build everything with it and  ship the libc of gcc-6 as a runtime dependency to my packages, `cling` works beautifully. They have much stronger requirements in terms of libc compatibility than a regular package because the *interpreted code* must use the exact same libc than the *compiled code* of the interpreter...

html: Hi, does anyone has a suggestion to keep a python project pip installable while actually installing as much as possible through the anaconda repositories? The current possibilities I see: have your requirements in setup.py (or requirements.txt) and copy them into a environment.yml file (while manually looking up if they are available on anaconda, which I don't find a great solution. Other possibility: write a small tool to check on anaconda what is available, en generate the environment.yml from setup.py, which has it's problems as well.

html:
@pvanderlinden you might want to use a conda recipe that draws from setup.py and/or requirements.txt. Bokeh does this, for example: https://github.com/bokeh/bokeh/blob/master/conda.recipe/meta.yaml#L39-L41

It is officially supported by conda-build, but not well-used, so if you encounter issues, be sure to post an issue on the conda-build issue tracker.

html: @msarahan - I looked at exactly that page but AFAICS it says nothing about respecting pre-release version order. All it says is that you can use a wildcard * to match anything (e.g. 1.4* matches 1.4, 1.4.1b2) but it doesn't mention anything about >=1.4b3 matching 1.4b4, 1.4rc0 but not 1.4a6.
text: @msarahan - I looked at exactly that page but  AFAICS it says nothing about respecting pre-release *version order*. All it says is that you can use a wildcard ` *` to match anything (e.g. `1.4*` matches  `1.4`, ` 1.4.1b2`) but  it doesn't mention anything about `>=1.4b3` matching `1.4b4`, `1.4rc0` but *not* `1.4a6`.

text: @dhirschfeld interesting. i don't really understand how either tool resolves dependencies, and how they share the site-packages folder. html: I think conda writes pip info so that pip is aware of conda installed packages but not the reverse. So a pip installed dependency would be cheerfully clobbered by conda which might have unintended sideeffects
text: I think conda writes pip info so that pip is aware of conda installed packages but not the reverse. So a pip installed dependency would be cheerfully clobbered by conda which might have unintended sideeffects

html: Is there any reason why otherwise identical packages in conda-forge have different dependencies from same packages in the defaults channel? This messes up installs when you have to add a package or two from conda-forge.
text: Is there any reason why otherwise identical packages in `conda-forge` have different dependencies from same packages in the `defaults` channel? This messes up installs when you have to add a package or two from `conda-forge`.

html: @rs2 every package ecosystem (i.e. channel) has its own choice of what software to build against. We call this concept the "core dependency tree" or CDT - what versions of low-level libraries make up your dependencies? The main constraint here is simply time. We (Anaconda) are working to use conda-forge recipes more directly, which will help us keep in sync more closely. However, it will be some time until we get there, and we're stuck with version mismatches until then.
text: @rs2 every package ecosystem (i.e. channel) has its own choice of what software to build against.  We call this concept the "core dependency tree" or CDT - what versions of low-level libraries make up your dependencies?  The main constraint here is simply time.  We (Anaconda) are working to use conda-forge recipes more directly, which will help us keep in sync more closely.  However, it will be some time until we get there, and we're stuck with version mismatches until then.

html:
@justlurking the downgrade is happening for four reasons:

  1. conda-forge only has the earlier version available
  2. when you install something with -c conda-forge, conda-forge is the highest priority channel
  3. channel priority is higher than version priority
  4. conda tries to always update itself

You can prevent this by disabling the last of those. https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/configuration/use-condarc.html#update-conda-automatically-auto-update-conda
text:

3. channel priority is higher than version priority
4. conda tries to always update itself

You can prevent this by disabling the last of those.  https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/configuration/use-condarc.html#update-conda-automatically-auto-update-conda

@anntzer Hmmm. Have you checked your site.py file? On macOS, my file says this at the beginning:

"""This will append site-specific paths to the module search path. On
Unix (including Mac OSX), it starts with sys.prefix and
sys.exec_prefix (if different) and appends
lib/python<version>/site-packages.
On other platforms (such as Windows), it tries each of the
prefixes directly, as well as with lib/site-packages appended. The
resulting directories, if they exist, are appended to sys.path, and
also inspected for path configuration files."""

html: The new miniconda that was pushed out yesterday has a new Python build, which is compiled with -fno-plt. This option is new in gcc 6.
text: The new miniconda that was pushed out yesterday has a new Python build, which is compiled with `-fno-plt`. This option is new in gcc 6.

html: An issue is that distutils.build_ext adds this flag automatically to the extension.
text: An issue is that `distutils.build_ext` adds this flag automatically to the extension.

html: It seems that this prevents building Python extensions with gcc 4.8, gcc 4.9 and gcc 5.
text: It seems that this prevents building Python extensions with `gcc 4.8`, `gcc 4.9` and `gcc 5`.

html: Thanks for letting us know. I recommend using our new compiler packages (gcc_linux-64) right now. @mingwandroid is on vacation right now, but we'll discuss this when he returns.

html: Hi, just stumbled on some problems with the hashes added to the dependencies in environment.yml (created using conda env export > environment.yml). Using conda env create -f environment.yml gives ResolvePackageNotFound and various other problems (specifically when building on a different system). Is there something I'm missing?
text: Hi, just stumbled on some problems with the hashes added to the dependencies in `environment.yml` (created using `conda env export > environment.yml`). Using `conda env create -f environment.yml` gives `ResolvePackageNotFound` and various other problems (specifically when building on a different system). Is there something I'm missing?

html: @drvinceknight environment.yml files which include build strings/build numbers are typically not portable between platforms
text: @drvinceknight environment.yml files which include build strings/build numbers are typically not portable between platforms

html:
Hey @drvinceknight you've probably stumbled onto a problem that's been brewing for a while, and the proliferation of hashes has finally sort of forced the issue. The conda issue count tagged under https://github.com/conda/conda/labels/tag%3Aenvironment-spec keep growing. That tag basically signifies the need to rework and clean up how we're doing environment manifests.

In the near-term, actually, today, I can work on a patch release to conda 4.3 that will add an extra flag to conda env export that strips off the build strings. That should at least take care of ~80% of the problem, for an immediate fix.
text:
Hey @drvinceknight  you've probably stumbled onto a problem that's been brewing for a while, and the proliferation of hashes has finally sort of forced the issue.  The conda issue count tagged under https://github.com/conda/conda/labels/tag%3Aenvironment-spec keep growing.  That tag basically signifies the need to rework and clean up how we're doing environment manifests.

In the near-term, actually, today, I can work on a patch release to conda 4.3 that will add an extra flag to `conda env export` that strips off the build strings.  That should at least take care of ~80% of the problem, for an immediate fix.

html: @drvinceknight and @kalefranz : that is definitely an issue. I’d love to have an option of having conda be “semver” aware and only (if requested) list major.minor, so patch and build numbers could be (optionally) dropped.
text: @drvinceknight and @kalefranz : that is definitely an issue.  I’d love to have an option of having conda be “semver” aware and only (if requested) list major.minor, so patch and build numbers could be (optionally) dropped.

html: After we release conda 4.4, we'll be able to create environment manifests that encapsulate only user-requested specs, and then let conda's solver fill in the rest. That should take care of many more of the portability issues. Really, I think there are only two types of environment descriptions we need to deal with... One is where you want to optimize for and maximize portability, and the second one is where you want to optimize for strict reproducibility, which is closer to the concept of a lock file.

html:
@dhirschfeld it is an internal policy that any recipe changes also change the build number. We recommend that externally as well. There is a timestamp field in the metadata (index.json), and conda uses this to break ties between otherwise-equivalent packages (ones that differ only by hash, for example).

However, with your point about build numbers, how are you supposed to judge that an incremented build number is going to make a reasonable change? With the knowledge about timestamps, build numbers and hashes are in the same boat: both encode some change, but tell you absolutely nothing about what that change is. Both arguably require some kind of diff-like tool that can tell you what changed between two packages.

However, with your point about build numbers, how are you supposed to judge that an incremented build number is going to make a reasonable change?  With the knowledge about timestamps, build numbers and hashes are in the same boat: both encode some change, but tell you absolutely nothing about what that change is.  Both arguably require some kind of diff-like tool that can tell you what changed between two packages.

text: ..so there are two builds of the same `pytables` package, one with a strict dependency on `hdf5  ==1.8.18` and the other with a strict dependency on `hdf5 ==1.10.1`

html: but the newer package is built against the older hdf5 which means updating pytables wants to downgrade hdf5
text: but the newer package is built against the older `hdf5` which means updating `pytables` wants to downgrade `hdf5`

html: AFAICS pytables works fine with with either version so perhaps a single package with 1.8.18|1.10.1 would have been more appropriate than two builds of the same package with mutually exclusive dependencies.
text: AFAICS `pytables` works fine with with either version so perhaps a single package with `1.8.18|1.10.1` would have been more appropriate than two builds of the same package with mutually exclusive dependencies.

html: I'm sure there must've been some reason for the current state, but it's not obvious to me...
text: I'm sure there must've been some reason for the current state, but it's not obvious to me...

html: I do not believe that the hdf5 library maintained ABI compatibility between 1.8.x and 1.10.x, see https://abi-laboratory.pro/tracker/timeline/hdf5/
text: I do not believe that the hdf5 library maintained ABI compatibility between 1.8.x and 1.10.x, see https://abi-laboratory.pro/tracker/timeline/hdf5/

html: If the ABI is broken or the SONAME changes then it is necessary to have two variant which have different version requirements.  If hdf5 1.10.1 was used to build the pytables packages it would not work with hdf5 1.8.18.
text: If the ABI is broken or the SONAME changes then it is necessary to have two variant which have different version requirements.  If hdf5 1.10.1 was used to build the pytables packages it would not work with hdf5 1.8.18.

html: That would make sense. It would then just be an unfortunate consequence of the timestamps that an update will select the version with the older hdf5 library when either are equally possible install plans.
text: That would make sense. It would then just be an unfortunate consequence of the timestamps that an update will select the version with the older hdf5 library when either are equally possible install plans.

html: @dhirschfeld yes, this is an unfortunate consequence of the timestamp-based prioritization. Conda 4.4 may improve things with its notion of explicitly-installed packages. I actually recommend filing an issue on the conda tracker. This behavior is tricky, and it's important for us to consider what "right" should be here. It will require tweaking the solver's list of optimization criteria.
text: @dhirschfeld yes, this is an unfortunate consequence of the timestamp-based prioritization.  Conda 4.4 may improve things with its notion of explicitly-installed packages.  I actually recommend filing an issue on the conda tracker.  This behavior is tricky, and it's important for us to consider what "right" should be here.  It will require tweaking the solver's list of optimization criteria.

text: Hey users and core developers of `conda`. I'd like to hear your views on the `conda` vs [`pipenv`](https://docs.pipenv.org/) [debate](https://jakevdp.github.io/blog/2016/08/25/conda-myths-and-misconceptions/)...

html: Where is the debate?
text: Where is the debate?

html: conda and pipenv have different goals and use cases.  A key main differences is pipenv manages Python packages, where as conda manages conda packages which can be anything including but not limited to Python packages.
