html: @amueller packages are mostly very interchangeable because we worked very hard to maintain compatibility. This is especially true for pure python stuff. So, we'll eventually rebuild everything with new tools, but where old stuff works, old stuff can still be used.
text: @amueller packages are mostly very interchangeable because we worked very hard to maintain compatibility.  This is especially true for pure python stuff.  So, we'll eventually rebuild everything with new tools, but where old stuff works, old stuff can still be used.

html: The easiest way to tell old stuff from new stuff on defaults is the hash, but that's changing with conda-build 3.1.0, released yesterday.
text: The easiest way to tell old stuff from new stuff on defaults is the hash, but that's changing with conda-build 3.1.0, released yesterday.

html: https://github.com/conda/conda-build/releases/tag/3.1.0
text: https://github.com/conda/conda-build/releases/tag/3.1.0

html: The new rules are basically meant to capture the thought of "if this package has binary compatibility issues, it needs a hash"
text: The new rules are basically meant to capture the thought of "if this package has binary compatibility issues, it needs a hash"

html: If packages use a compiler in their build, they need a hash, because which compiler changes the compatibility of that package
text: If packages use a compiler in their build, they need a hash, because *which* compiler changes the compatibility of that package

html: similarly, if a package depends on something that we pin (generally for ABI compatibility), it needs a hash.
text: similarly, if a package depends on something that we pin (generally for ABI compatibility), it needs a hash.

html: anything else, any pure python stuff, is fine without a hash
text: anything else, any pure python stuff, is fine without a hash

html: So, with that change, the next best way is to look at where the package came from.  If it came from repo.continuum.io/pkgs/free, it's old.
text: So, with that change, the next best way is to look at where the package came from.  If it came from repo.continuum.io/pkgs/free, it's old.

html: if it came from repo.continuum.io/pkgs/main, it's new
text: if it came from repo.continuum.io/pkgs/main, it's new

html: and failing that, you'd need to look at the runtime dependencies of your package.  Stuff built with new compilers will have different runtime dependencies, such as libstdcxx-ng or libgcc-ng, as opposed to libgcc

text:
Hi, how can I remove conda package without triggering update of other packages in the envrionment? 
I have conda 4.4.4, I want to remove ``nbpresent`` and conda wants to update itself to 4.4.6. 
I do not see any option in ``conda remove --help`` that would only remove the package without updating the conda. 

Is ``conda`` package special case here, or it would try to update all other packages?

html: conda remove nbpresent --force
text:
```
conda remove nbpresent --force
```

html:
--force               Forces removal of a package without removing packages
                        that depend on it. Using this option will usually
                        leave your environment in a broken and inconsistent
                        state.
How conda can depend on nbpresent?

html: Is there a way to deactivate a conda environment in python?
text: Is there a way to deactivate a conda environment in python?

html: FWIW here is a related SO question that has not yet been answered, if there is a preference for Gitter over SO.
text: FWIW here is a related [SO question]( https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45807042/activate-a-conda-environment-in-python-script ) that has not yet been answered, if there is a preference for Gitter over SO.

html: Deactivating an environment requires to modify the shell's environment which cannot be done from a subprocess like python.
text: Deactivating an environment requires to modify the shell's environment which cannot be done from a subprocess like `python`.

html: So I thought there was some hackery like this in conda-build where it would run deactivate in a subprocess and export the environment variables and set them in the Python environment. Didn't know if it got codified into something more formal.
text: So I thought there was some hackery like this in `conda-build` where it would run deactivate in a subprocess and export the environment variables and set them in the Python environment. Didn't know if it got codified into something more formal.

html: If you don't want to deactivate the Conda environment in the parent shell process, but instead do it for a subprocess, this is entirely possible. IIRC, there is none such functionality readily available. IIRC, conda-build just launches a new sub-shell in which a new environment is activated. Note that trying to alter the environment of the calling Python process wouldn't be a good idea since you will continue to run that Python interpreter instead of the one from the activated environment. You should use a new Python subprocess, i.e. from the calling Python instance run something akin to subprocess.check_call(["bash", "-c", "source activate env && python do_stuff.py"]).
text: If you don't want to deactivate the Conda environment in the parent shell process, but instead do it for a subprocess, this is entirely possible. IIRC, there is none such functionality readily available. IIRC, `conda-build` just launches a new sub-shell in which a new environment is activated. Note that trying to alter the environment of the calling Python process wouldn't be a good idea since you will continue to run that Python interpreter instead of the one from the activated environment. You should use a new Python subprocess, i.e. from the calling Python instance run something akin to `subprocess.check_call(["bash", "-c", "source activate env && python do_stuff.py"])`.

html: @SylvainCorlay "slowness in the evenings" could in the most simple case just be a very local thing, e.g., people in your neighborhood coming home, watching Netflix/etc. and thus "stealing" the bandwidth. Sounds stupid, but that can always be a possibility if an ISP's connection doesn't have enough capacity.. Otherwise, what Mike said, a CDN is used (not only for defaults but also anaconda.org, I think) -- if that CDN doesn't perform like it should, you should tell Anaconda about it.

html: To the best of my knowledge, anaconda.org is not behind a CDN, or not actively cached.  I know it's something we want to do, but it's also a different beast from defaults, which is totally static.  anaconda.org is dynamic, so it needs something like varnish to cache a given channel's index appropriately.  I would expect that CDN for the actual files should be easy, but there's additional complexity here in agreements with CDN providers over exactly what's covered.

Hi all. After upgrading from 4.3.x to 4.4.7, I'm finding that conda env update --prune --file env.yaml isn't removing packages as I expected when they are removed from the env file, and this is causing conflicts. The same command was working OK in 4.3.
eg, after changing the env file to take Python from 2.7.12 -> 3.6.2 and removing cffi=1.10.0=py27_0, I get:

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - cffi==1.10.0=py27_0 -> python=2.7
  - python==3.6.2=0
Use "conda info <package>" to see the dependencies for each package.

...even though cffi is no longer in the env file at all. Is this expected behaviour that I'm misunderstanding, or should I create a bug report for this? Thanks!
text:
Hi all. After upgrading from 4.3.x to 4.4.7, I'm finding that `conda env update --prune --file env.yaml` isn't removing packages as I expected when they are removed from the env file, and this is causing conflicts. The same command was working OK in 4.3.
eg, after changing the env file to take Python from 2.7.12 -> 3.6.2 and removing `cffi=1.10.0=py27_0`, I get:
```
UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - cffi==1.10.0=py27_0 -> python=2.7
  - python==3.6.2=0
Use "conda info <package>" to see the dependencies for each package.
```
...even though cffi is no longer in the env file at all. Is this expected behaviour that I'm misunderstanding, or should I create a bug report for this? Thanks!

html: @ShannonGreen Yes, please create a bug report. Make sure to include all the information needed to reproduce the problem, including the env.yaml file you're using.
text: @ShannonGreen Yes, please create a bug report.  Make sure to include all the information needed to reproduce the problem, including the env.yaml file you're using.

html: Quick q re conda compiler packages? If one is building a C++ package and is using a conda-provided compiler then what's the recommended way of ensuring that the right C++ std lib is linked to at runtime? a) {{ compiler('cxx') }} a build and runtime dependency or b) {{ compiler('cxx') }} a build dep and libgcc as a run-time dep (w/ the same version as {{ compiler('cxx') }}?
text: Quick q re conda compiler packages?  If one is building a C++ package and is using a conda-provided compiler then  what's the recommended way of ensuring that the right C++ std lib is linked to at runtime?  a) `{{ compiler('cxx') }}` a build _and_ runtime dependency or b) `{{ compiler('cxx') }}` a build dep and `libgcc` as a run-time dep (w/ the same version as `{{ compiler('cxx') }}`?

html: Using conda build 3, all that is needed is to include {{ compiler('cxx') }} as a build requirement. The correct run requirements are added automatically via run exports, https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/define-metadata.html#pin-downstream
text: Using conda build 3, all that is needed is to include `{{ compiler('cxx') }}` as a build requirement.  The correct run requirements are added automatically via run exports, https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/define-metadata.html#pin-downstream

html: @WillFurnass_twitter just to add a tiny bit to what Jonathan said, we make special effort to ignore and/or deprioritize system libraries. You would actually have to work pretty hard to link to the wrong c++ std lib (at build time). The run_exports functionality is what makes sure the right version is present at runtime.
text: @WillFurnass_twitter just to add a tiny bit to what Jonathan said, we make special effort to ignore and/or deprioritize system libraries.  You would actually have to work pretty hard to link to the wrong c++ std lib (at build time).  The run_exports functionality is what makes sure the right version is present at runtime.

html: Quick question regarding the new compilers: Currently there is no new gcc available for osx-64. Am I right to assume that likely there won't be a gcc/gxx on osx-64 build/packaged by Anaconda anytime soon? Just asking because it could very well be that there are a couple (I don't really know how many, but I hope only a few) packages on Bioconda that are GCC-only for whatever reasons.
text: Quick question regarding the new compilers: Currently there is no new `gcc` available for `osx-64`. Am I right to assume that likely there won't be a `gcc`/`gxx` on `osx-64` build/packaged by Anaconda anytime soon? Just asking because it could very well be that there are a couple (I don't really know how many, but I *hope* only a few) packages on Bioconda that are GCC-only for whatever reasons.

html: I would expect anything that's gcc-only to be that way because of fortran.  We still have gfortran.  We haven't built new gfortran, but we can if necessary.  I think it's more likely that you'd see flang develop enough and people would go for an all-llvm stack on osx (and maybe other OS's as time goes on)
text: I would expect anything that's gcc-only to be that way because of fortran.  We still have gfortran.  We haven't built new gfortran, but we can if necessary.  I think it's more likely that you'd see flang develop enough and people would go for an all-llvm stack on osx (and maybe other OS's as time goes on)

text: I am trying to get pytorch installed on power9 system. currently trying to get the dependencies first, is there a mkl recipe for power8/9?

html: also, I have been playing around with building recipes. Generally there is the meta.yaml and build.sh files in the respective recipe directory. But for the mkl intel "recipe" there are no such files. How does that work?
text: also, I have been playing around with building recipes. Generally there is the meta.yaml and build.sh files in the respective recipe directory. But for the mkl intel "recipe" there are no such files. How does that work?

html: mkl is an intel product.  They do not support Power architecture.
text: mkl is an intel product.  They do not support Power architecture.

html: The intel MKL recipe is a repackaging of Intel's existing packages. The recipe for those is at https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/intel_repack-feedstock
text: The intel MKL recipe is a repackaging of Intel's existing packages.  The recipe for those is at https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/intel_repack-feedstock

html: you probably want to build pytorch against openblas
text: you probably want to build pytorch against openblas

html: which is an alternative to mkl

html: @jjhelmus has done the most work on openblas with Power architecture. he may be able to give you some pointers to example recipes.

html:
By a process of elimination (aka whack-a-mole) I was able to find that it is in fact arrow-cpp which doesn't like pytorch:
λ conda create -n torch python=3.6* pytorch arrow-cpp
Solving environment: failed

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - arrow-cpp
  - pytorch
Use "conda info <package>" to see the dependencies for each package.
text:
By a process of elimination (aka whack-a-mole) I was able to find that it is in fact `arrow-cpp`  which doesn't like `pytorch`:
```
λ conda create -n torch python=3.6* pytorch arrow-cpp
Solving environment: failed

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - arrow-cpp
  - pytorch
Use "conda info <package>" to see the dependencies for each package.
```

html:
Digging deeper:
λ conda create -n junk vc=14.1 arrow-cpp
Solving environment: failed

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - arrow-cpp -> vc==14
  - vc=14.1
text:
Digging deeper:
```
λ conda create -n junk vc=14.1 arrow-cpp
Solving environment: failed

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be in conflict:
  - arrow-cpp -> vc==14
  - vc=14.1
```

html:
So the issue seems to come down to the vc package:
vc 14.1 h21ff451_0
------------------
dependencies:
    vs2017_runtime >=15.4.27004.2010,<16.0a0


arrow-cpp 0.8.0 py36_vc14_3
---------------------------
dependencies:
    numpy >=1.12
    python 3.6*
    snappy
    vc 14


vc 14 h0510ff6_3
----------------
dependencies:
    vs2015_runtime >=14.0.25123,<15.0a0
text:

    python 3.6*
    snappy
    vc 14

    
vc 14 h0510ff6_3
----------------

```

html: To make matters more confusing, conda-build (3) interprets vc 14 as vc 14.* to avoid unnecessary unsatisfiable dependencies.
text: To make matters more confusing, conda-build (3) interprets ``vc 14`` as ``vc 14.*`` to avoid unnecessary unsatisfiable dependencies.

html: This will sort itself out over time (as packages are built with conda-build 3, and improved recipes) they'll get the bounded-style vc constraint. For now, you'll need to fix the packages that conflict - probably relax the vc 14 constraint to be vc 14.* - you can't go the other way because newer things won't work with the older runtime.
text: This will sort itself out over time (as packages are built with conda-build 3, and improved recipes) they'll get the bounded-style vc constraint. html: I found these instructions discussing installing Anaconda on an air-gapped computer. It does not mention the other packages.
text: I found [these instructions](https://docs.anaconda.com/anaconda/faq#how-can-i-install-anaconda-on-an-air-gapped-computer) discussing installing Anaconda on an air-gapped computer.  It does not mention the other packages.

html: @StevenCHowell There might be a better way, but one thing you can do is download the appropriate .tar.bz2 package files, either from https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/free/linux-64/ / https://anaconda.org/conda-forge/THE_PACKAGE_NAME / get it from your anaconda/pkgs after conda installing on a machine with the same architecture, then just run conda install whatever.tar.bz2 on the airgapped computer. You'll need to make sure you get all the right versions of the dependencies yourself, though; conda won't check this for you this way.
text: @StevenCHowell There might be a better way, but one thing you can do is download the appropriate `.tar.bz2` package files, either from https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/free/linux-64/ / https://anaconda.org/conda-forge/THE_PACKAGE_NAME / get it from your `anaconda/pkgs` after `conda install`ing on a machine with the same architecture, then just run `conda install whatever.tar.bz2` on the airgapped computer. You'll need to make sure you get all the right versions of the dependencies yourself, though; conda won't check this for you this way.

Hi, all. I'm trying to use conda 4.4's MatchSpec to explicitly specify channels in an environment.yml file. If env.yml contains:

dependencies:
- defaults::requests=2.11.1=py27_0
- timl::wxpython=4.0.0rc1.dev3440+0f9b36e=py27_0

and I run, conda env update -n foo -f env.yml --prune, then requests still comes from the timl channel. I've also tried with anaconda instead of defaults. Is this supposed to work, or am I missing something?
text:
Hi, all. I'm trying to use conda 4.4's MatchSpec to explicitly specify channels in an environment.yml file. If env.yml contains:
```
dependencies:
- defaults::requests=2.11.1=py27_0
- timl::wxpython=4.0.0rc1.dev3440+0f9b36e=py27_0
```
and I run, `conda env update -n foo -f env.yml --prune`, then `requests` still comes from the `timl` channel.  I've also tried with `anaconda` instead of `defaults`. Is this supposed to work, or am I missing something?

html: Ah. I looked at the source for conda-env and it seems like it doesn't yet understand this syntax.
text: Ah. I looked at the source for conda-env and it seems like it doesn't yet understand this syntax.

html: If your env.yml only contains a list of dependencies, you could also convert that into a text file (one match specification per line, no leading -) and use it with the normal non--env conda commands via the --file argument.
text: If your `env.yml` only contains a list of dependencies, you could also convert that into a text file (one match specification per line, no leading `- `) and use it with the normal non-`-env` `conda` commands via the `--file` argument.

html: If you run that outside of your script, then this would put the conda executable on PATH. If you run it inside of the script, then the script can use the shell function. There are some features, e.g., automatic environment reactivation, that the shell function provides. So if you install/remove packages with (de)activation script into the currently activated environment, you'd want to use the shell function, i.e., source conda.sh inside your script.
text: If you run that outside of your script, then this would put the `conda` executable on `PATH`. If you run it inside of the script, then the script can use the shell function. There are some features, e.g., automatic environment reactivation, that the shell function provides. So if you install/remove packages with (de)activation script into the currently activated environment, you'd want to use the shell function, i.e., source `conda.sh` inside your script.

html: The issue here is that it's potentially really confusing for users. If I'm delivering a script that is supposed to create an env and install all our dependencies in to it, until 4.4 they didn't need to do anything other than the required conda set up (putting the base env's bin on $PATH). Now they have to activate the base env before they run the script.
text: The issue here is that it's potentially really confusing for users. If I'm delivering a script that is supposed to create an env and install all our dependencies in to it, until 4.4 they didn't need to do anything other than the required conda set up (putting the base env's `bin` on `$PATH`). Now they have to activate the base env before they run the script.

html: I can't do it in the script because I don't know where conda is installed if they don't activate the base env. But that wasn't the case before.
text: I can't do it in the script because I don't know where conda is installed if they don't activate the base env. But that wasn't the case before.

html: If nothing else, an exported env var for the path to conda.sh would be sufficient.
text: If nothing else, an exported env var for the path to `conda.sh` would be sufficient.

html: Because the function stuff is pretty transparent to users, so it's not going to be readily apparent why they can run conda on the command line but if they call my script in the same shell, it can't run conda.
text: Because the function stuff is pretty transparent to users, so it's not going to be readily apparent why they can run `conda` on the command line but if they call my script in the same shell, it can't run `conda`.

html: With conda >=4.5.0 you can also run "${CONDA_EXE}" create -nenv ...
text: With `conda >=4.5.0` you can also run `"${CONDA_EXE}" create -nenv ...`

html: Ah. Any chance that can be backported to 4.4?
text: Ah. Any chance that can be backported to 4.4?

html: Any reason not to update to 4.5?
text: Any reason not to update to `4.5`?

html: Since it's a new (albeit small) feature, I'm not sure we should put this into a patch release.
text: Since it's a new (albeit small) feature, I'm not sure we should put this into a patch release.

html: It's not my conda, it's the people who use our software, so I don't control all the condas out there.
text: It's not my conda, it's the people who use our software, so I don't control all the condas out there.

html: Might be a new feature but 4.4 was a fundamental change to the way conda deals with its environment, so the lack of a way to deal with that from within scripts is a deficiency (from my perspective).
text: Might be a new feature but 4.4 was a fundamental change to the way conda deals with its environment, so the lack of a way to deal with that from within scripts is a deficiency (from my perspective).

html: I'd encourage your users to update to 4.5. Not because of that feature, but because 4.5 fixed a bug that could (in certain situations) allow conda itself to be removed.
text: I'd encourage your users to update to `4.5`. Not because of that feature, but because `4.5` fixed a bug that could (in certain situations) allow `conda` itself to be removed.

html: So 4.4 should be considered unstable at this point?
text: So 4.4 should be considered unstable at this point?

html:
Definitely consider 4.5 more stable. Not sure if we should call 4.4 unstable per se (and I don't know if it's planned to backport that fix). I for myself consider 4.5 a 4.4+, i.e., something very similar but better :wink:.
For reference CONDA_EXE was introduced in conda/conda#6923.
The mentioned bug was fixed with conda/conda#6929. (And that reminded me, it was not that conda possibly removed itself but rather its dependencies -- but nonetheless cripple itself.)
text:
Definitely consider `4.5` more stable. Not sure if we should call `4.4` unstable per se (and I don't know if it's planned to backport that fix). I for myself consider `4.5` a `4.4+`, i.e., something very similar but better :wink:.
For reference `CONDA_EXE` was introduced in https://github.com/conda/conda/pull/6923.
The mentioned bug was fixed with https://github.com/conda/conda/pull/6929. (And that reminded me, it was not that `conda` possibly removed itself but rather its dependencies -- but nonetheless cripple itself.)

html: the two concepts are different.  A package is something frozen at a particular snapshot in time
text: the two concepts are different.  A package is something frozen at a particular snapshot in time

html: you can create an env for development, and then use python setup.py develop or pip install -e . to install a library in develop mode in that env

Hi, I have noticed that as of recently, new Windows Conda environments no longer contain Scripts\activate.bat or Scripts\conda.bat. Until now, I was using Scripts\activate.bat to execute various commands in scripts within the activated environment.

I have found conda-wrappers, which helps somewhat for executing, e.g., python, ipython, jupyter, etc.

However, is there any way to find the conda.exe used to create the environment in the first place? I would like to discover this path so I can use it to script, e.g., installing new packages into the environment, without having explicitly add the root Conda environment to the path.
text:
Hi, I have noticed that as of recently, new Windows Conda environments no longer contain `Scripts\activate.bat` or `Scripts\conda.bat`.  Until now, I was using `Scripts\activate.bat` to execute various commands in scripts within the activated environment.

I have found [`conda-wrappers`](https://anaconda.org/conda-forge/conda-wrappers), which helps somewhat for executing, e.g., `python`, `ipython`, `jupyter`, etc.

However, is there any way to find the `conda.exe` used to create the environment in the first place?  I would like to discover this path so I can use it to script, e.g., installing new packages into the environment, without having explicitly add the root Conda environment to the path.

html:
Looks like this is related to conda/conda#7126.

It seems like the removal of Scripts\conda and Scripts\activate in environments was deliberate. As a work around, pinning conda<4.4 seems to do the trick for now.

Does anyone know the motivation behind this change? What is the canonical way of dealing with this in the future?
text:
Looks like this is related to [`conda/conda#7126`: "With conda being a shell function in 4.4+, what's the suggested way to use conda via scripts when an environment isn't explicitly activated by the user beforehand?"](https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/7126).

It seems like the removal of `Scripts\conda` and `Scripts\activate` in environments was deliberate.  As a work around, pinning `conda<4.4` seems to do the trick for now.

Does anyone know the motivation behind this change?  What is the canonical way of dealing with this in the future?

@ishtjot It seems like you might be confusing two different things:
  • Making a conda environment with a different python version. That’s what https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/getting-started.html#managing-environments is about; you’d do e.g. conda create -n py3 python=3.5.
  • Building a package of some software that can be installed with conda. That’s what conda build does, and it has nothing really to do with creating environments.

html: is there a convenient command to get the recipe of a conda package? Often I need to build the recipe on a strange system, it would be great to directly get the recipe from a conda related command. Instead of going: create folder, wget tar.bz2 file , tar -xf , find recipe directory, mv recipe directory, rename and cleanup.
text: is there a convenient command to get the recipe of a conda package? Often I need to build the recipe on a strange system, it would be great to directly get the recipe from a conda related command. Instead of going: create folder, wget tar.bz2 file , tar -xf , find recipe directory, mv recipe directory, rename and cleanup.

html: @zeneofa not really. The recipe that gets baked into the package is likely specific to the system it was built on. The meta.yaml.template file might be what you want. However, if the existing meta.yaml does indeed work for you, you can just extract the tarball and point conda-build at the root of the package. Conda-build recurses through all the folders and finds any meta.yaml file you have in there. If there's more than one, it barfs because it is ambiguous which one it should use.
text: @zeneofa not really.  The recipe that gets baked into the package is likely specific to the system it was built on.  The meta.yaml.template file might be what you want.  However, if the existing meta.yaml does indeed work for you, you can just extract the tarball and point conda-build at the root of the package.  Conda-build recurses through all the folders and finds any meta.yaml file you have in there.  If there's more than one, it barfs because it is ambiguous which one it should use.

html: Are there any docs or other resources showing how to use conda programmatically - i.e. from python rather than the command line?
text: Are there any docs or other resources showing how to use conda programmatically - i.e. from python rather than the command line?

html: Is this use case well supported?
text: Is this use case well supported?

html: Do you mean using conda as a library? Or activating and using an environment programatically, like what conda run used to be?
text: Do you mean using conda as a library? Or activating and using an environment programatically, like what `conda run` used to be?

html: Using conda as a library
text: Using conda as a library

html:
I'm not aware of any docs regarding that. In general, conda has four public interfaces for programmatic use:

  • conda.api,
  • conda.exports,
  • conda.cli.python_api,
  • and running conda in a subprocess while providing the --json argument.

The former two expose mostly some internal or lower level functionalities. conda.api is rather new and everything is marked as "Beta" (and I have no experience with it, yet :wink:). conda.exports is what is used in conda-build or similar tools.
The latter two are roughly equivalent. The difference is mostly just that conda.cli.python_api is directly called from Python code and doesn't need a subprocess. If you want a high level interface, you should use one of those two.
As for "well supported": all of the above are public interfaces and are thus supported. conda subcommand --json is likely the "most" supported. Though, conda.exports exists a long time and has its "regular customer" in conda-build. I don't think conda.cli.python_api is widely used, but it should be fairly decent in that it mirrors the CLI (see its doc strings/source code or its uses in conda's own tests for usage examples).
text:
I'm not aware of any docs regarding that. In general, `conda` has four public interfaces for programmatic use:
- `conda.api`,
- `conda.exports`,
- `conda.cli.python_api`,
- and running `conda` in a subprocess while providing the `--json` argument.

The former two expose mostly some internal or lower level functionalities. `conda.api` is rather new and everything is marked as "Beta" (and I have no experience with it, yet :wink:). `conda.exports` is what is used in `conda-build` or similar tools.
The latter two are *roughly* equivalent. The difference is mostly just that `conda.cli.python_api` is directly called from Python code and doesn't need a subprocess. If you want a high level interface, you should use one of those two.
As for "well supported": all of the above are public interfaces and are thus supported. `conda subcommand --json` is likely the "most" supported. Though, `conda.exports` exists a long time and has its "regular customer" in `conda-build`. I don't think `conda.cli.python_api` is widely used, but it should be fairly decent in that it mirrors the CLI (see its doc strings/source code or its uses in `conda`'s own tests for usage examples).

html: But note that to use conda.cli.python_api, you'll have to have conda installed in the same environment as the tool/library you want it to access from. I believe this is the reason why anaconda-navigator calls conda in a subprocess (at least I think it still does).
text: But note that to use `conda.cli.python_api`, you'll have to have `conda` installed in the same environment as the tool/library you want it to access from. I believe this is the reason why `anaconda-navigator` calls `conda` in a subprocess (at least I think it still does).

html: That’s just how python sys.path works though. If you want to import conda, then conda has to be somewhere on sys.path.
text: That’s just how python sys.path works though. If you want to `import conda`, then `conda` has to be somewhere on sys.path.

html: Note that as of conda 4.4, you can install conda in any environment, not just the original base environment.
text: Note that as of conda 4.4, you can install conda in *any* environment, not just the original base environment.

html: However when you do that, you create a new instance of the conda executable, and then you have a separate base environment for that new executable.
text: However when you do that, you create a new instance of the conda executable, and then you have a separate `base` environment for that new executable.

html: That behavior of a new base environment is certainly confusing for most users. (Yet another reason I think we should be stressing environment locations and not environment names.) I’ve been thinking about making some type of hard-coded special case that skips linking the bin/conda executable when installing conda in a non-base environment.
text: That behavior of a new base environment is certainly confusing for most users. (Yet another reason I think we should be stressing environment *locations* and not environment *names*.) I’ve been thinking about making some type of hard-coded special case that skips linking the `bin/conda` executable when installing conda in a non-base environment.

html: conda uses a Boolean satisfiability (SAT) solver when determining what packages to install or add/remove from an environment.  I am not too familiar with pipenv but I believe it installs dependencies recursively and does not check if a dependency conflicts with already installed packages.
text: conda uses a Boolean satisfiability (SAT) solver when determining what packages to install or add/remove from an environment.  I am not too familiar with pipenv but I believe it installs dependencies recursively and does not check if a dependency conflicts with already installed packages.

html: @mariusvniekerk @jjhelmus What I think I noticed was that pipenv would install x, y, z serially, whereas conda install x y z can resolve dependency jointly. One-liner works much better than three separate installs (where the ordering may alter configuration), e.g. in Travis builds using pip vs conda. So any insight here algorithmically?
text: @mariusvniekerk @jjhelmus What I think I noticed was that `pipenv` would install x, y, z serially, whereas `conda install x y z` can resolve dependency jointly.  One-liner works much better than three separate installs (where the ordering may alter configuration), e.g. in Travis builds using `pip` vs `conda`. So any insight here algorithmically?

html: @rsvp I believe they already answered you. Conda uses a SAT solver that considers the problem as a whole. pip and pipenv are recursive (and thus serial).
text: @rsvp I believe they already answered you.  Conda uses a SAT solver that considers the problem as a whole.  pip and pipenv are recursive (and thus serial).

html: I think they are related but orthogonal.  conda-pack is meant for deploying identical environments several places.  It was designed for use with Spark clusters, for example.

html: Hosting packages locally is for reducing bandwidth usage primarily.  It's not about creating identical envs - it's about making a certain set of packages available, which users can use to create arbitrary (not necessarily identical) envs

html: I'm not sure where this ought to go, as a feature request, but I often wish the Conda package listing included a link to the build recipe.
text: I'm not sure where this ought to go, as a feature request, but I often wish the Conda package listing included a link to the build recipe.

html:
That's not really possible afaik. At the time the package is built, the recipe is often part of a git clone. We have easy access to where it is on disk, and some commit info. We do record some info in the conda package, in the info/recipe/meta.yaml file:

# This file created by conda-build 3.10.9
# meta.yaml template originally from:
# C:\ci\containers\0000388ceic\tmp\build\80754af9\rsync-recipes\toml-0.9.4-python_3.6-on-winbuilder, last modified Mon Jun 25 11:37:12 2018
# ------------------------------------------------

In our build system, it is not in a git repo, so you don't get commit info.

You may be able to inspect what origin is and add to that, but that is not always going to be possible. I wanted to do that sort of thing, and can't remember why it wasn't possible.

You can file an issue for the feature request on the conda-build issue tracker, but this will be very low priority and probably won't get done without a community contribution.
text:
That's not really possible afaik.  At the time the package is built, the recipe is often part of a git clone.  We have easy access to where it is on disk, and some commit info.  We do record some info in the conda package, in the info/recipe/meta.yaml file:

```
# This file created by conda-build 3.10.9
# meta.yaml template originally from:
# C:\ci\containers\0000388ceic\tmp\build\80754af9\rsync-recipes\toml-0.9.4-python_3.6-on-winbuilder, last modified Mon Jun 25 11:37:12 2018
# ------------------------------------------------
```

In our build system, it is not in a git repo, so you don't get commit info.

You may be able to inspect what ``origin`` is and add to that, but that is not always going to be possible.  I wanted to do that sort of thing, and can't remember why it wasn't possible.

You can file an issue for the feature request on the conda-build issue tracker, but this will be very low priority and probably won't get done without a community contribution.

text:
The [conda documentation](https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/create-custom-channels.html) states you can reference a custom conda channel from a local directory using `file://opt/channel/`.  How does `file://opt/channel/` translate to a Windows file system?  I have found different versions of different slash combinations, some that look like they are for network drives, but I have not been able to get any to work.  I keep getting the same error: 
```
CondaHTTPError: HTTP 404 CONNECTION FAILED for url <file://s:/anaconda_pkgs/noarch/repodata.json>
Elapsed: 00:02.278231

The remote server could not find the noarch directory for the
requested channel with url: file://anaconda_pkgs

```

html:
@loader_path/
          This  variable  is replaced with the path to the directory containing the mach-o binary which contains the load command using @loader_path. Thus, in every binary, @loader_path resolves to a different path, whereas @executable_path
          always resolves to the same path. @loader_path is useful as the load path for a framework/dylib embedded in a plug-in, if the final file system location of the plugin-in unknown (so absolute paths cannot be used) or if the plug-in
          is used by multiple applications (so @executable_path cannot be used). If the plug-in mach-o file is at /some/path/Myfilter.plugin/Contents/MacOS/Myfilter and a framework dylib file is at /some/path/Myfilter.plugin/Contents/Frame-
          works/Foo.framework/Versions/A/Foo, then the framework load path could be encoded as @loader_path/../Frameworks/Foo.framework/Versions/A/Foo and the Myfilter.plugin directory could be moved around in the file system and dyld  will
          still be able to load the embedded framework.
text:
@loader_path/
              This  variable  is replaced with the path to the directory containing the mach-o binary which contains the load command using @loader_path. Thus, in every binary, @loader_path resolves to a different path, whereas @executable_path
              always resolves to the same path. @loader_path is useful as the load path for a framework/dylib embedded in a plug-in, if the final file system location of the plugin-in unknown (so absolute paths cannot be used) or if the plug-in
              is used by multiple applications (so @executable_path cannot be used). If the plug-in mach-o file is at /some/path/Myfilter.plugin/Contents/MacOS/Myfilter and a framework dylib file is at /some/path/Myfilter.plugin/Contents/Frame-
              works/Foo.framework/Versions/A/Foo, then the framework load path could be encoded as @loader_path/../Frameworks/Foo.framework/Versions/A/Foo and the Myfilter.plugin directory could be moved around in the file system and dyld  will
              still be able to load the embedded framework.

html: Does anyone know what might be causing this issue: jupyterlab/jupyterlab#4918
text: Does anyone know what might be causing this issue: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/4918

html: When I install jupyterlab using conda-forge it uses python however when installing using from the default channel it used pythonw, and this causes issues with DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH
text: When I install `jupyterlab` using conda-forge it uses `python` however when installing using from the default channel it used `pythonw`, and this causes issues with DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH

html: I believe the difference stems from the use of osx_is_app: True in the recipe.
text: I believe the difference stems from the use of `osx_is_app: True` in the recipe.

html: That would make sense.
text: That would make sense.

html: Do you know why people recommend pythonw over python for apps?
text: Do you know why people recommend `pythonw` over `python` for apps?

html: pythonw is recommended when the script uses a GUI
text: pythonw is recommended when the script uses a GUI

html: it avoids popping up a separate console on windows
text: it avoids popping up a separate console on windows

html: Reading more about this from here: ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues#199
text: Reading more about this from here: https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/199

html: It seems that pythonw is only really required for applications that need access to the window on OSX
text: It seems that `pythonw` is only really required for applications that need access to the window on OSX

html: since jupyter lab is just a web application, it may not need to be built with that flag
text: since jupyter lab is just a web application, it may not need to be built with that flag

html: I agree, let me ask some other Anaconda team members
text: I agree, let me ask some other Anaconda team members

html: jupyterlab prior to 0.27.0 did not have the entry if you want to try out an older version
text: jupyterlab prior to 0.27.0 did not have the entry if you want to try out an older version

html: @kdheepak note that the underlying issue is that pythonw is a bash script, and macOS since 10.12 removes DYLD_ variables from the environment when launching binaries in protected system directories (e.g.: /bin/bash). This is annoying and broke all sorts of things, but just an FYI because you may run in to the issue again when using software launched via bash on mac.
text: @kdheepak note that the underlying issue is that pythonw is a bash script, and macOS since 10.12 removes DYLD_ variables from the environment when launching binaries in protected system directories (e.g.: /bin/bash). This is annoying and broke all sorts of things, but just an FYI because you may run in to the issue again when using software launched via bash on mac.

html: (or via bash script I should say)
text: (or via bash *script* I should say)
